reviews.title: Nice experience
reviews.text: We just stay there for one day ahead of our cruise trip, it's a nice hotel link to the Knight Convention Center. The MetroMover is right there, walking inside the tunnel without going outside under the heat. A lot of constructions around that area.
Hotel staff are very friendly. And when the check-in/out line was long, they immediately add some more staff to help you. However, the room design is a little bit interesting.
reviews.title: Old 2 star hotel faking it as a 4 star

reviews.text: We stayed here one night on Dec. 30th. I wanted a "special" night at a 4 star hotel. Well, half the hotel is under renovation and is closed. BTW, this is the half with the ocean view. We tried 3 rooms and all smelled bad. The hotel is dark and depressing. The rooms stink and as others have said they have balconies but they are shut so you get no fresh air. The pool was also closed. If you are looking for a place to sleep for one night and can get a $50 bid on priceline, it might be OK. Otherwise, skip this place.
reviews.title: Great customer service, hotel is improving with current renovation

likes.disliked: — Windows no longer open, room balcony now closed, river smell in hallways

reviews.text: I stayed at this hotel 2 years ago, and it was a dump, it needed renovation badly. I just return and I am happy to report the rooms have been nicely renovated. I had a corner room with a view of the Miami River, and all these empty condo towers that now dominate the Miami Sky Line. Rooms now have a nice plasma TV. Hyatt Grand Bed, nice seating area, and are nicely decorated. The meeting areas have also been completed. The Regency Club, Pool Area, and restaurants are currently being worked on as of 12/25/07. Food service is good to great, depends on what you order. There is decent fitness room where you can get a good work out. Customer Service was good to excellent.
reviews.title: Definitely Not Hyatt Quality or 4 Star at that!

reviews.text: One thing I really liked was that the Metro Mover is just a short walk through the convention center, which connects to the Miami Metro Rail. South Beach, Coral Gables, and Coconut Grove are just a short drive/cab ride away. The location is centrally located to enjoy all of Miami.

reviews.title: Not bad, but still remodeling.
reviews.text: My family stayed at the Hyatt Regency Miami for two nights from Feb 9 to Feb 11 of 2008. Our room was kinda of small but was clean and appeared to have just been remodeled. The room had a flat screen tv and all the small amenities. The only problem was that when we got to the hotel you could not get any ice from the ice maker. They were still remodeling part of the hotel and all the ice machines did not work, you had to go the the first floor restaurant to get ice. I complained to the front desk and they gave me a small refrigerator for two nights for free. This was our first time to miami and the bell men and service desk really knew where everything was to see. They gave great directions to all the attractions. Bayside Marketplace was only about 6 blocks away and you can really walk to it during the day. There is a CVS store close to the hotel. At night its not the safest to walk around as there are alot of bums around. I would stay there again once they fully remodel this place. The convention center that is connected to the hotel is pretty old. Self parking is not bad and its only like $12.50 a night.

I won a trip to Miami and this is the hotel my son and I stayed at. It was clean, the staff was friendly and the food was good. The room was big the layout I must admit a bit strange, but I have only one complaint was the valet parking was very expensive, so we parked next door in the parking garage for a lot less.

reviews.text: The Hyatt is in a good location in Miami - close to the port for people going on cruises and just beyond the port is South Beach. The rooms in the Hyatt were setup differently from every other hotel I have been in and were very appealing. The rooms had just been renovated and still had that new smell to them. We were going to use the self checkin but there was nobody else at the checkin desk so just checked in as normal. Staff was friendly and fast at processing check in. The only area that could have used some work was the actual bathrooms. The room was obviously renovated but the actual bathroom had not been touched. The caulking around the bath tub was roughly done and the tiles were slightly greyed due to age. Not a major deal but was a noticeable difference.

reviews.text: A large, generic American hotel. We had a "Miami Suite"-catagory room (No 638) which had a nice view onto Brickell Bridge and the Miami River but, alas, was fairly noisy because of the traffic crossing the metal grid on the bridge and music from passing party-boats. The room is triangular in shape but large and comfortable. The furniture and general interior are kept in beige and brown tones and look quite tired but everything is reasonably clean and functional. Bed and mattress good. Room service reliable. Certain cosmetic items (toothpaste, vanity kit etc.) are complimentary but have to be requested. Bath ok but also has a used look and feel.

The breakfast buffet carries a good variety of warm and cold food, including smoked salmon, fresh fruit and a daily special of egg benedict. Marmalade, jams and honey are imported from Switzerland (the miniature "Hero" glass jars). I am Swiss and I like our products but surely it does not make sense to ship these heavily packaged goods across the Atlantic when there MUST be some good Floridian orange marmalade?

reviews.text: The gym is fairly small but during our stay there was never any congestion. ATM machine, pool, terrace, sports bar, souvenir shop, health spa all in the main building. There is a business centre too, but internet use is USD 10 for 15 minutes even for hotel guests which is, frankly, ridiculous. Wireless LAN in your room also expensive (1 hour USD 3.95, 1 day USD 10). WiFi should be free in EVERY hotel, but particularly in a business venue like the Mimai Hyatt.

reviews.text: I stayed here for four days at a conference in August. It was the convention hotel, and it's a fine one at that. The staff is helpful and knowledgeable, the rooms are updated and clean, and the restaurants decent. It's connected to Miami's downtown Metro rail system, which connects you to the nearby convention center, the financial district, and the bayfront. There are some decent restaurants one or two Metro stops away, but the hotel isn't very convenient to anything in "right-next-door" easy walking distance (except for a neat little ethnic bar and grill next door, where the owner promotes "Jeb Bush's Favorite..." specials. Wonderful place and great conversation with the owner! I can't remember the name, but it's the only restaurant that's next door to the hotel.) The hotel (and this bar and grill) front a working waterway, but the Hyatt provides no tables and chairs or other opportunities to sit right outside the hotel and enjoy this amenity. The hotel is a 15-minute cab ride to South Beach, or a 30-minute bus ride on a C or K bus that you can catch three or four blocks from the hotel. I used the bus for the ride over to South Beach, and caught a cab on the way back. There's an Enterprise rental car office on site, which is very useful, except that it closes at 6 p.m. on weeknights and isn't open Sundays. That means you have to pay to park your car overnight ($12 self-park and more in the hotel valet) if you return after hours.

The renovations seem to be just about done and the previous problems reported in other reviews seem to have been resolved. I personally do not like Miami, but the Hyatt was certainly comfortable for the two days I was there and the staff was certainly attentive.
reviews.title: A nice business hotel

reviews.text: I had a conference at the Hyatt Miami and after reading the previous posts listed here, I was really nervous about it. Hubby and I stayed and had a wonderful time. The room was comfortable and nice and clean. After a day or two, the bathroom had a weird smell, but overall our stay was great. Smell went away also. Hotel staff is very accommodating and friendly. The MetroMover located right next to the hotel was very convenient. We took it to Bayside and Brickell. Bayside was great for restaurants, shopping, and boat tours. Not so impressed with Brickell as they are still undergoing construction. There were a few restaurants there but not quite ready for visitors. A taxi to South Beach was approx $20 and well worth it. Taxi to Parrot Jungle was about $13. The balcony doors still aren't able to be opened and there is a ton of construction around but our stay wasn't disturbed by any noise. It is a concrete jungle, but it's not as bad as some of the previous posts will have you believe.
reviews.title: Pleasant Stay at Hyatt Miami

reviews.text: A conference my wife attended over a weekend in March '08 was located at this hotel. The renovation construction referenced by other reviewers must be complete. Our room was updated and clean with new furniture and a flat screen TV. The bathroom was also clean. The bed was WONDERFUL. The staff was extremely helpful and willing to please; they exceeded my expectations. The swimming pool is open. Taxi cabs are available onsite 24 hours a day.

reviews.text: I just spent several nights at the Hyatt Regency Miami for a conference. It was a mostly unpleasant experience. The room had one of the worst, moldy smells I have ever encountered in a hotel, certainly in a Hyatt. I complained to the front desk and they did send someone to check on the A/C (there was moisture on the floor in front of it). There was a little card in my room that maintenance had visited, but I think the room smelled worse after they visited. The odor was pervasive throughout the hotel though, not just in the room. There was construction/renovation underway, but the odor was not one attributable to construction (though two of the days my floor also had pervasive solvent odors).
reviews.title: What a smell!

reviews.text: In addition, these were some of the worst conference rooms I have experienced - poor lighting, bad sound systems. And for the rooms that had dividers the sound leakage from adjacent meeting rooms was so invasive that it was nearly impossible to concentrate, or hear, what was being presented in the session I was attending.

reviews.text: I have stayed in many Hyatts over many, many years of business travel, and this was by far the worst one I have encountered. I seriously considered checking out and finding any hotel I could within the vicinity, but that was a challenge of its own. The Hyatt is completely surrounded by half-completed (and apparently halted) high-rise construction, freeways, and incredibly busy roads. It was virtually impossible to figure out how to walk anywhere from the concrete locked space.

reviews.text: Smokers - which I am not! - take note: smoking is only permitted in rooms on the 15th floor so if this is important to you, confim and confirm again a room allocation. Because although there are balconies from each room, they are now merely decorative and a rather misleading feature of publicity shots! The hotel is now sealing all balcony doors so you have no access to them, in an attempt to minimise construction noise and reduce in-room humidity. However, this is a shame, as it is nice to be able to pop out for a few minutes or have a drink on the balcony etc. especially in mild temperatures. I see they make no mention of the balconies as a room feature on the website. All I'm saying is, don't let the pictures fool you!

reviews.text: I stayed here because of a conference in this hotel. I do not recommend this hotel for anything except business trips or a one night stay to connect with a cruise ship. The hotel is showing its age and while they have renovated the rooms, the bathrooms are still small and show their heritage from a time when bathrooms were a necessity and not considered part of a luxury hotel stay. Our room faced the Bay but because of numerous condos under construction, our view was one of a concrete structure under construction. We could wave to the workers. It was also noisy. The draw bridge has an annoying way of waking you all through the night.
